Well here's the explaination : the ball corves towards the LEFT, because it's spinning Counterclockwise. As it hits the beam, it bounces off at an angle equal to the angle of incidence (the angle of incidence is measured between he imaginary line that the ball travels on...in this case it's a curve, instead. we use the tangent and the perpendicular line on hat surface, within the same plain as the trajectory. And the angle of reflection is the same - equal. ) So the ball bounces off at an angke, but is still has some angular momentum (it's still  spinning) and it curves to the lefy again, and it hits the bar again, then it bounces off for the last time, as it's treveled past the gate and cannot hit anything else on the way down to the ground.

COOL! I came across this video while looking for the Veritasium's video on the same subject for my daughter science project. I am happy to have found +Physics Girl!

As an aeronautical engineer and speaker I have been frequently in the situation of explaining wing’s lift to groups of people, and spinning cylinders and balls (specially golf ones) are always part of the explanation. The video itself and the most of the comments are a playground to joyfully discuss the matter.

It was somehow a surprise to hear the simpler (but correct) explanation based on Newton’s third law. Going the Bernoulli’s way (when explained correctly) is very lengthy. The only correction that I would point out is at min 2:00 she says that a “buildup of air… …creates a higher pressure on that side and pushes the ball”, which is equivalent to the lower side of a wing, or intrados. More important than the higher pressure, is the lowest pressure produced at the other side (upper side of a wing, or extrados). The net difference from the location atmospheric pressure is higher at the “extrados” than at the “intrados”, thus more important for lift (or Magnus force in this case) is the extrados. That explains why military aircraft carry all their unwanted deadly stuff below the wing, without severely affecting lift.

A nice article on the effect with great CFD images of the phenomenon, and a discussion on the effect of the ball seams can be seen here: http://www.comsol.com/blogs/magnus-effect-world-cup-match-ball/

ok, it hit twice because the forward momentum was converted to angular momentum when friction between the ball and goal beam caused the ball to spin faster.  Since it was spinning faster but traveling more slowly forward the combination of a much lower pressure on the goal side due to the faster spin and it traveling more slowly forward when conservation of momentum converted forward momentum to angular momentum it had time to move normal to the forward path and striking the goal before it left the length of the goal.

Yes I think it's because of the extreme spin, as well as the extremely acute angle of incidence and therefore the resultant acute angle of reflection (made even more acute when the spinning ball hits the crossbar the first time). Also, I may be wrong, but I believe the goalposts had flat sides (rather than the typical cylindrical posts) so that could also have contributed - cylindrical posts tend to distort the angle of reflection depending on where the ball strikes it and also provide a smaller surface area for the striking ball to spin off of)

My thoughts on the double-hit. It appears to just be an extreme fluke. The ball hits the angle of the cross-bar in such a way that it is propelled a little up and a little out (instead of hitting flush against the upward face and bouncing up/behind, or instead of hitting flush against the side face and bouncing away) The collision friction is not enough to stop the spin of the ball (and actually appears to impart a good amount of additional angular momentum during the collision). So as the ball is bounced slightly upward and slightly away, the spin and therefore the Magnus force increases and 'pulls' it back in to the post again. Million dollar shot. Not quite as fluke-y as this: Miracle half-court shot stuck on rim

Confusion (the effect from Newton's third law):

You say that BECAUSE the net air flow is from left to right, that the ball has to move in the opposite direction.... which isn't clear to me at all. I understand that the rocket is an example of recoil...which satisfies Newton's third law.

Am I right then to think that the air molecules near the surface of the spinning ball, are being dragged and thrown at a direction effectively perpendicular to the trajectory? This would then make sense as recoil.

Edit: "effectively perpendicular" isn't right. The air particles are being dragged in a path with perpendicular and tangential components. The tangential component of the push is however of no interest as it just speeds the ball up along its path.
